body: cc @hachikuji , could we ever get the map of records with some of the partition containing empty set?
@guozhangwang, @hachikuji, what happens when we have fewer records than `TopicPartition`s? The empty `TopicPartitions` aren't in the map?

And if it's the case that we assume no partition has an empty set of records, perhaps it's worth asserting that in the constructor with something like a `Preconditions.checkArgument(!entry.getValue().isEmpty())` for each entry of `records`. I'd be happy to make that change if that's preferable.

@guozhangwang I think we currently only add to ConsumerRecords non-empty record sets (or this would have been found much sooner). That said, the change seems fine to me and protects anyone who construct ConsumerRecords instances in test cases where record sets may be empty.

@drausin Do we really need powermock to test this? Couldn't you just pass in a Map with a couple empty record lists and verify that the ConsumerRecords iterator behaves correctly?

@hachikuji, definitely don't need PowerMock, though I think it makes the test a tad cleaner, since we don't have to create a bunch of dummy instances.  That said, I'm happy to abide by the conventions/practices of the codebase, so I'll update the test per your suggestion.
LGTM. cc @guozhangwang @junrao
@ijuma @ewencp @granders could you have a look, thanks. Note this PR is just about fixing the failure a subsequent one will update the tests to include the 0.10 scenario.
Can you explain the reasoning for this change @granthenke?
LGTM

The configuration for block.on.buffer.full was changed from a default of `true` to `false` during [KAFKA-2120](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2120). With a brief search through code reviews and discussions I couldn't find why it was changed. 

@MayureshGharat @jjkoshy Can you help provide some insight?

If this was intended to be changed, this patch should update the docs and include a warning in the 0.9 upgrade notes. Otherwise we may want to change back to a value of `true` (as this PR currently does)

Currently the block.on.buffer.full docs read as follows:

> When our memory buffer is exhausted we must either stop accepting new records (block) or throw errors. **By default this setting is true** and we block, however in some scenarios blocking is not desirable and it is better to immediately give an error. Setting this to false will accomplish that: the producer will throw a BufferExhaustedException if a recrord is sent and the buffer space is full.
@ijuma I was typing up a comment to start the discussion. You are just too fast. :)
@gwenshap Can you please merge this?
@jholoman pointed this issue out (Thanks!). He may have some comment on the impact it has/had.

@becketqin I think the important question here is how to make it easy for clients to handle the exceptions (whether it's a client-side or broker-side exception is less important in my opinion). Having very similar exceptions thrown from different places can be confusing (eg RequestTimeoutException from callback/Future.get versus TimeoutException on the caller thread). Also, there is the compatibility question to consider.

@guozhangwang's suggestion 2) could be considered a bug fix. The larger refactoring you have suggested would require a KIP, in my opinion.
Sure, I have some concerns with changing the default w/out documenting. My understanding is that having this set to false and not handling the BufferExhaustedException could lead to data loss.
@junrao Thanks for the confirmation. I understand json version will change.
@granthenke The conditional delete patch has been merged into zkclient. Do you want to give it a try with a build of zkclient master to see if it is good?

@granthenke The property block.on.buffer.full is no longer used as per kafka-2120 and was supposed to be removed in future releases. This will require some changes to the KafkaProducer code. I am not sure if this is the right time to remove this property. If yes, I can get a patch ready for the same. 

P.S: Kafka-2120 deprecates few other properties as well. We can also get rid of those if we are fine with it.

@MayureshGharat Thanks for the response. I will need to dig in a bit to understand the change. We definitely need to update docs if its not being used anymore. Its also referenced in the current javadoc:
- https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/KafkaProducer.java#L122
- https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/KafkaProducer.java#L423

If this has been deprecated, nothing in the documentation indicated that, and provides the alternative. The  `@deprected` tag will only trigger for those using the variable, but many will likely configure with a file or raw strings.

@MayureshGharat Looking a bit further the default for max.block.ms (the replacement for block.on.buffer.full) is set to 60 seconds. Which means the default behavior is close to the old default for block.on.buffer.full which was `true`. Was there a reason, even if deprecated, block.on.buffer.full was changed to false? 

It's probably valuable to  update the 0.9 upgrade docs to tell users that they need to handle `BufferExhaustedException` exception now by default.

@ijuma and I are simultaneously commenting today. :)

@ijuma I see that. This is close to the old behavior but not exactly the same if 60 seconds passes. So users will get an exception they may not have been expecting before. I think, at a minimum, we should document it both in the code and on the site docs.

@granthenke Users will get a TimeoutException from BufferPool.allocate ( no more BuffereExhaustException) : 
**throw new TimeoutException("Failed to allocate memory within the configured max blocking time");**

We decided to deprecate it since we wanted to get rid of the property and basically make it simple to the end-users to rely on only two properties going forward : 
1) max.block.ms
2) request.timeout.ms

The users will get warning when they try to use the deprecated properties. But once we remove these deprecated properties, we need to update the docs to reflect the change.

@MayureshGharat Is there somewhere I, and any user of a KafkaProducer, can learn about this change and the new exceptions they should handle (in the callback?) and the exceptions they no longer need to handle?  

The properties are deprecated and behavior has changed. I think we need to update the site docs and java docs now. I can open a jira to track that.

@granthenke AFAIK, I don't think there are docs representing that info. The users need to handle the TimeoutException which they should have been doing earlier as well. The only thing is now they do not have to care about BufferExhaustException.
 Can you open a jira. I can work on it right away.
Thanks @MayureshGharat! I created [KAFKA-3393](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3393) to track that.

@fpj I tested locally on 0.8-dev and get a lot of test failures. The failures look like they are related to a change that went into zkclient after your change: https://github.com/sgroschupf/zkclient/commit/2c8f4e907b22b16455f781aa518a85f6ec0c18fc

The stacktrace from the tests is:

```
org.I0Itec.zkclient.exception.ZkAuthFailedException: Authentication failure
    at org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient.waitForKeeperState(ZkClient.java:946)
    at org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient.waitUntilConnected(ZkClient.java:925)
    at org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient.connect(ZkClient.java:1230)
    at org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient.<init>(ZkClient.java:156)
    at org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient.<init>(ZkClient.java:130)
    at kafka.utils.ZkUtils$.createZkClientAndConnection(ZkUtils.scala:80)
    at kafka.utils.ZkUtils$.apply(ZkUtils.scala:62)
    at kafka.zk.ZooKeeperTestHarness$class.setUp(ZooKeeperTestHarness.scala:67)
    at kafka.server.LogOffsetTest.setUp(LogOffsetTest.scala:48)

java.lang.NullPointerException
    at kafka.server.LogOffsetTest.tearDown(LogOffsetTest.scala:59)
```
@hachikuji cool, I will leave it for you to review then.
@becketqin I also agree with you about the issues of mixing the TimestampException and RetriableException in the hierarchy, though they may need a KIP to change as @ijuma said.
@granthenke I also made that change to throw an exception when auth fails. I need to have a closer look to see why it is throwing an exception in those cases.

I thought that we should also take care of existing compatibility_test.py as part of the same patch. We just had a discussion with @granders and @ewencp and concluded that we should just remove those tests completely, because they are testing an expected failure and will always succeed until we change an error message (which we did, this is why they are now failing).

Then, I think it's better to have your tests in compatibility_test.py file.
@MayureshGharat I think we need to update the 0.9 upgrade site docs too with a note on the default and behavior change.
Closing this since its now tracked by #1060

@ijuma I agree that it is all about how to make it easy for user to handle the exceptions. But I think having exceptions with "similar" names but clear meaning is much better than shoehoning seemingly same exceptions into one exception but conveying wrong information. 

In ApiException, error code 7 (Request Timeout) has a very clear meaning about what happened: the broker had to send back a produce response before the message is successfully replicated because the request timeout in the produce request has reached. On the client side, we map this error code to TimeoutException.

Currently we are re-purposing this TimeoutException for all the other cases where a timeout is needed on the client side. I think separating TimeoutException and RequestTimeoutException make it very clear that TimeoutException is not an ApiException returned by broker, but simply means the client cannot finish something in time. It is just a client side exception. To me it makes it much easier for user to handle. 

I agree that we need a KIP for the exception hierarchy change.

@granthenke Can you take a look at the upgrade doc, if it looks ok? 
Also I am planning to open a jira for the other issue that I mentioned above. Does that sound right?
I'm not sure this issue has actually been resolved. It may still make sense to add retry behavior at least in the case of send failures, which pop up sometimes in commitAsync().

@ijuma I'm open for suggestions. Here are the best options I think. I didn't want to use `KAFKA_OPTS` because it's most likely to be overridden. Should I add a new variable? If so do you have a suggestion of what I should use? 

```
KAFKA_JVM_PERFORMANCE_OPTS
KAFKA_OPTS
```
LGTM, unit test passed locally. Merged to trunk.
@Ishiihara Could you rename the ticket name as `MINOR: [description]` since it will be used in the commit title?
@guozhangwang Added some description.
LGTM, merged to trunk.

Ping @ijuma @junrao for review.

Note that I've preserved the behavior of the old requests which translate null metadata to an empty string. I also considered allowing the internal OffsetMetadata object to represent the metadata as an Option, but I decided not to since it's exposed in the SimpleConsumer.
LGTM
@zhuchen1018, it would be good to include a test for this.
Do we still need the original function that requires long serdes?
Ping @ymatsuda @miguno and @ijuma for reviews. The wrapper and factory class was added in `org.apache.kafka.common.serialization` so we want to make sure if it is generally applicable.

This depends on and includes https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1042

Ideally #1042 would be merged first.
Thanks for the update. Changes look good. Just waiting for tests to finish running on my machine before I merge :)
LGTM
It is kind of hard to review due to the overlap with 1042. Does it need rebase now that 1042 was merged?
Done. Sorry for the delay :)

What if a user wants to use an empty string as a valid key? I think using null to represent no-key and assuming any other value is a key is safest. If a user want's they can put this logic in their client or even provide their own partitioner with custom logic.
LGTM. Thanks for the updates @MayureshGharat.

@Ishiihara In addition to the comments already included, the new `ConnectorPluginsResource` has not been added to `RestServer`. The unit tests will pass, but the resource will not be available when you actually execute a worker (and unfortunately, right now `RestServer` doesn't have real testing).
That's right @gwenshap, I have rebased now.
@granders Ok, removed these two tests from trunk. New compatibility tests are now part of KAFKA-3188. Thanks.
@guozhangwang, can you please review this? My oversight for not including the test with the original PR.
@gwenshap, maybe you can review this.

@granthenke It is fixed in 0.8-dev, I checked it locally myself. Let me know if it works for you too. I was also thinking that we might need to switch to zkclient 0.8 first, before checking in this patch. Otherwise, we will break trunk.

@fpj The patch as currently written still uses the workaround. The change for zkclient 0.8 is still local. 

This patch fixes a big enough issue that I think it should get in for the next release with or without zkclient 0.8. If that means committing it as is, and then a follow up when 0.8 is available that works for me. But even with the un-optimal delete behavior, its still safer than it was before.

@granthenke I was assuming that you want to have the conditional delete in with this patch, but if it is not the case, then sure, we don't need to switch to 0.8 with the workaround. I'm definitely not disputing the importance of the issue.
@fpj I do want the conditional delete. I get that via `zkUtils.zkConnection.getZookeeper.delete(path, expectedVersion)` like you recommended. I think that is okay until zkclient 0.8 is available.

@granthenke Ok, just to clarify, the zkclient folks will release 0.8 as soon as we say that the changes work for us, so if you want to have this in for 0.10, we need to make sure that the changes work so that we can flag it to them. Once they release, we upgrade kafka to use zkclient 0.8 and assuming everyone is happy with this PR, we can merge it, in this order. Does it sound right to you?

@fpj Gotcha. I didn't understand that we had control over the zkclient release. I will test today and report back. Unless you think it should be 2 separate patches, I am happy to include the 0.8 bump in this patch.
@granthenke I was proposing two patches to separate concerns, but you're right that we could just do it all here.
Review by @hachikuji and @gwenshap
@fpj I can do it in 2 steps. I will open a jira to track the upgrade change and make this depend on it.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM. Could you rebase?
@allenxwang, the following merges master into your branch: https://github.com/allenxwang/kafka/pull/5

@guozhangwang wrote:

> Do we still need the original function that requires long serdes?

Personally I don't see a reason why we'd continue to need the original function that requires the user to explicitly pass in a `LongSerializer`/`LongDeserializer`.  I'd remove it.

The only reason would be if our serde was broken or not efficient enough, in which case we'd rather prefer people to file a JIRA and improve it for all users instead of "getting away" with it by passing in a custom one. ;-)
@fpj I created KAFKA-3403 to track the upgrade. I tested zkclient locally and everything passes.

@granthenke ok, sounds good. do you think you can test a version of your patch with the conditional delete call? It'd be good to make sure that we don't have anything unexpected due to the conditional delete changes.
@fpj Yeah, that is what I tested.
@guozhangwang :  This PR does not update the Streams examples, but it should.
LGTM

NP. Thanks :)

-Mayuresh

cc @gwenshap
This seems like a good change although I haven't tested it. I assume you did @granthenke?

Yes, I tested this by running `gradle clean releaseTarGz` before and after the change. I compared the files of the new and old tar outputting the jars the were de-duplicated via: 

``` bash
comm -2 -3 \
   <(ls -R kafka_2.10-0.10.0.0-SNAPSHOT-old | sort) \
   <(ls -R kafka_2.10-0.10.0.0-SNAPSHOT | sort)
```

The untared release went from ~61MB to ~34MB.

I do encourage reviewers to test as well though.
Ah, you beat me to it. The other option is to add a new error code (as discussed with @junrao), but I think this patch is the way to go for now.
LGTM
@gwenshap ping for review. I have verified this using the system test added as part of KAFKA-3380.
@gwenshap ping again. Once we have this in, I can provide a patch for updating old producer usage in SimpleConsumerShell.
LGTM
I am not going to add parameter descriptions because they will be replaced soon by the serde unification.
LGTM. Since this is a small change compared with https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1066, I'm going to merge in this PR first and rebase the latter.
Merged to trunk.
LGTM, thanks @ijuma ! Merged to trunk.
I rebased against trunk and added a commit to use the non-deprecated `Broker` constructor (now that the rack-aware PR has been merged).
Hmm, I need to do more work to reduce warnings in tests, so closing until that's done.
LGTM

Sorry, I'm super confused.
From what I see, the getOffsetTool never used the old producer (or can you point me to the line in the code where it does?), but after your change it uses the new Producer even if you have an "useOldProducer" flag?

ok, I got it. The old producer is actually hiding in client utils.

Any special reason we are keeping it around as an option? When do we expect users to use this?
@gwenshap the tools uses `ClientUtils.fetchTopicMetadata` on line 111, which uses old producer, https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/core/src/main/scala/kafka/client/ClientUtils.scala#L55.

Same timing :). No specific reason, just wanted to be consistent with other tools, where we did not remove old producer, but just made new producer as default option. Once we plan to remove old producer, we can remove all usages of old producer. That is my thought, I am happy to remove it if you think that is the way to go.
If we have both options, perhaps the system test should test both?
Yea, that sounds fair. I will update the test. Thanks!

It seems like the failure is probably unrelated since a similar issue existed before, and we've reopened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3290 to address that failure. This LGTM otherwise, so I'm going to commit this and we can follow up on that very transient failure in 3290.
